not too many people sit in the back seats and so we've not really concentrated our efforts there okay so there's no doubt in your mind that if it were require that there be shoulder harnesses everywhere your kids would be okay and a lot more people would be alive absolutely I mean you don't have to look at the injuries my wife and I received and the injuries my boys received and the answer is right there okay now what happened in the lawsuit well the first thing happened in the lawsuit a couple of documents turned up early and Discovery and one of these was dated 1967

and it was from the head of force biomechanical engineering department to his superiors and it was the results of their study they done on the feasibility of lap and shoulder belt as opposed to lap only belt he concluded this memo by saying there was no question a lap and shoulder belt provided far more safety than lap belt alone but for didn't pay attention to the memo they paid no attention at all and in fact in 1971 72

they did some more extensive tests with Crash Test Dummies that concluded that a person in a rear seat wearing a lap belt in an impact of 36 to 45 miles an hour only had a two percent chance of survival compared to 98% chance had that person been wearing a lot of and short the harness Bellwood it goes to put a shoulder harness in the back well in 1986 where 1985 when our car was built it would have cost $12 per belt and that included all the retooling that would have been
